thread.title: Melton Mowbray pork pies, Leicestershire cheese and Rutland beer under threat if US gets its way post-Brexit

author: Oliver Astley
title: Melton Mowbray pork pies, Leicestershire cheese and Rutland beer under threat if US gets its way post-Brexit
text:

The US food and drinks industry is putting pressure on the UK government to remove laws that protect Melton Mowbray pork pies, Rutland bitter and Leicestershire-made Stilton cheese. 
After Brexit, American manufacturers want the UK to drop the European Union rules that protect speciality products, reports the i newspaper . 
Currently, only pork pies made within and around Melton and using a traditional recipe are allowed to have the name Melton Mowbray on the packaging. 
Rutland bitter can only be brewed within Rutland and Leicestershire while Stilton cheese can only be produced in Leicestershire, Derbyshire or Nottinghamshire. 
When the UK leaves the EU, US lobbyists would like these rules removed for its manufacturers to be able to export copycat products around the world, potentially damaging local producers. Read More 
As well as the Melton Mowbray pork pie, Stilton cheese and Rutland bitter, relaxing the rules would potentially threaten the Cornish pasty, the Cumberland sausage, Jersey Royal potatoes, Scotch whisky, Plymouth gin and Wensleydale cheese. Stilton can only be made in Leicestershire, Derbyshire or Nottinghamshire 
Manufacturers with lower costs and wider distribution would be able to produce cheaper versions of these products and sell them to supermarkets and retailers around the world. 
Cheese, in particular, is one of the specific markets that the US is hoping to exploit. 
The i reports that the US Dairy Export Council is lobbying on post-Brexit trade deals, arguing for a fresh look at UK regulation that would allow American manufacturers to produce cheeses that are currently protected. Read More Waitrose takes dessert off the menu over pieces of plastic 
If the UK ditches the Protected Designation of Origin rules after leaving the EU,British producers would potentially be able to sell sparkling wine as 'Champagne' but the door would also be open for international firms to make Melton Mowbray pies, Rutland bitter and Stilton overseas then sell them to supermarkets such as Asda, Tesco, Morrisons and Sainsbury's, undercutting traditional manufacturers.
